lines.text: Enter MARIA and Clown

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I will not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter in way of thy excuse: my lady will hang thee for thy absence.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Let her hang me: he that is well hanged in this world needs to fear no colours.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Make that good.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: He shall see none to fear.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: A good lenten answer: I can tell thee where that saying was born, of 'I fear no colours.'

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Where, good Mistress Mary?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: In the wars; and that may you be bold to say in your foolery.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Well, God give them wisdom that have it; and those that are fools, let them use their talents.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent; or, to be turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage; and, for turning away, let summer bear it out.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: You are resolute, then?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Not so, neither; but I am resolved on two points.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: That if one break, the other will hold; or, if both break, your gaskins fall.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Apt, in good faith; very apt. Well, go thy way; if Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece of Eve's flesh as any in Illyria.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my lady: make your excuse wisely, you were best.
Exit

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Wit, an't be thy will, put me into good fooling! Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft prove fools; and I, that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man: for what says Quinapalus? 'Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit.' God bless thee, lady!
Enter OLIVIA with MALVOLIO

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Take the fool away.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Go to, you're a dry fool; I'll no more of you: besides, you grow dishonest.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel will amend: for give the dry fool drink, then is the fool not dry: bid the dishonest man mend himself; if he mend, he is no longer dishonest; if he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Any thing that's mended is but patched: virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin; and sin that amends is but patched with virtue. If that this simple syllogism will serve, so; if it will not, what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but calamity, so beauty's a flower. The lady bade take away the fool; therefore, I say again, take her away.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Sir, I bade them take away you.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, cucullus non facit monachum; that's as much to say as I wear not motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to prove you a fool.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Can you do it?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Dexterously, good madonna.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Make your proof.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I must catechise you for it, madonna: good my mouse of virtue, answer me.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I'll bide your proof.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Good madonna, why mournest thou?

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Good fool, for my brother's death.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother's soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? doth he not mend?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him: infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox; but he will not pass his word for two pence that you are no fool.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: How say you to that, Malvolio?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal: I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that has no more brain than a stone. Look you now, he's out of his guard already; unless you laugh and minister occasion to him, he is gagged. I protest, I take these wise men, that crow so at these set kind of fools, no better than the fools' zanies.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste with a distempered appetite. To be generous, guiltless and of free disposition, is to take those things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon-bullets: there is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do nothing but rail; nor no railing in a known discreet man, though he do nothing but reprove.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
Re-enter MARIA

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: From the Count Orsino, is it?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: I know not, madam: 'tis a fair young man, and well attended.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Who of my people hold him in delay?

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Fetch him off, I pray you; he speaks nothing but madman: fie on him! Go you, Malvolio: if it be a suit from the count, I am sick, or not at home; what you will, to dismiss it. Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and people dislike it.
Exit MARIA
Exit MALVOLIO

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest son should be a fool; whose skull Jove cram with brains! for,--here he comes,--one of thy kin has a most weak pia mater.
Enter SIR TOBY BELCH

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: By mine honour, half drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: A gentleman.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: A gentleman! what gentleman?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: 'Tis a gentle man here--a plague o' these pickle-herring! How now, sot!

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Good Sir Toby!

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Lechery! I defy lechery. There's one at the gate.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Ay, marry, what is he?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not: give me faith, say I. Well, it's all one.
Exit

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: What's a drunken man like, fool?

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Like a drowned man, a fool and a mad man: one draught above heat makes him a fool; the second mads him; and a third drowns him.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Go thou and seek the crowner, and let him sit o' my coz; for he's in the third degree of drink, he's drowned: go, look after him.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: He is but mad yet, madonna; and the fool shall look to the madman.
Exit
Re-enter MALVOLIO

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you. I told him you were sick; he takes on him to understand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you. I told him you were asleep; he seems to have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speak with you. What is to be said to him, lady? he's fortified against any denial.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Tell him he shall not speak with me.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Has been told so; and he says, he'll stand at your door like a sheriff's post, and be the supporter to a bench, but he'll speak with you.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: What kind o' man is he?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Why, of mankind.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: What manner of man?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Of very ill manner; he'll speak with you, will you or no.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Of what personage and years is he?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy; as a squash is before 'tis a peascod, or a cooling when 'tis almost an apple: 'tis with him in standing water, between boy and man. He is very well-favoured and he speaks very shrewishly; one would think his mother's milk were scarce out of him.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Let him approach: call in my gentlewoman.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
Exit
Re-enter MARIA

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Give me my veil: come, throw it o'er my face. We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.
Enter VIOLA, and Attendants

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: The honourable lady of the house, which is she?

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Speak to me; I shall answer for her. Your will?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty,--I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her: I would be loath to cast away my speech, for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn; I am very comptible, even to the least sinister usage.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Whence came you, sir?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question's out of my part. Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Are you a comedian?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: No, my profound heart: and yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you the lady of the house?

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself; for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve. But this is from my commission: I will on with my speech in your praise, and then show you the heart of my message.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Come to what is important in't: I forgive you the praise.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: It is the more like to be feigned: I pray you, keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates, and allowed your approach rather to wonder at you than to hear you. If you be not mad, be gone; if you have reason, be brief: 'tis not that time of moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Will you hoist sail, sir? here lies your way.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: No, good swabber; I am to hull here a little longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet lady. Tell me your mind: I am a messenger.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of war, no taxation of homage: I hold the olive in my hand; my words are as fun of peace as matter.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Yet you began rudely. What are you? what would you?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I learned from my entertainment. What I am, and what I would, are as secret as maidenhead; to your ears, divinity, to any other's, profanation.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Give us the place alone: we will hear this divinity. Now, sir, what is your text?
Exeunt MARIA and Attendants

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Most sweet lady,--

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it. Where lies your text?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: In Orsino's bosom.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: In his bosom! In what chapter of his bosom?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: O, I have read it: it is heresy. Have you no more to say?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Good madam, let me see your face.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate with my face? You are now out of your text: but we will draw the curtain and show you the picture. Look you, sir, such a one I was this present: is't not well done?
Unveiling

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Excellently done, if God did all.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: 'Tis in grain, sir; 'twill endure wind and weather.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on: Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive, If you will lead these graces to the grave And leave the world no copy.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted; I will give out divers schedules of my beauty: it shall be inventoried, and every particle and utensil labelled to my will: as, item, two lips, indifferent red; item, two grey eyes, with lids to them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you sent hither to praise me?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I see you what you are, you are too proud; But, if you were the devil, you are fair. My lord and master loves you: O, such love Could be but recompensed, though you were crown'd The nonpareil of beauty!

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: How does he love me?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: With adorations, fertile tears, With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Your lord does know my mind; I cannot love him: Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble, Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth; In voices well divulged, free, learn'd and valiant; And in dimension and the shape of nature A gracious person: but yet I cannot love him; He might have took his answer long ago.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: If I did love you in my master's flame, With such a suffering, such a deadly life, In your denial I would find no sense; I would not understand it.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Why, what would you?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Make me a willow cabin at your gate, And call upon my soul within the house; Write loyal cantons of contemned love And sing them loud even in the dead of night; Halloo your name to the reverberate hills And make the babbling gossip of the air Cry out 'Olivia!' O, You should not rest Between the elements of air and earth, But you should pity me!

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: You might do much. What is your parentage?

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well: I am a gentleman.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Get you to your lord; I cannot love him: let him send no more; Unless, perchance, you come to me again, To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well: I thank you for your pains: spend this for me.

lines.speaker: viola
lines.text: I am no fee'd post, lady; keep your purse: My master, not myself, lacks recompense. Love make his heart of flint that you shall love; And let your fervor, like my master's, be Placed in contempt! Farewell, fair cruelty.
Exit

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: 'What is your parentage?' 'Above my fortunes, yet my state is well: I am a gentleman.' I'll be sworn thou art; Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions and spirit, Do give thee five-fold blazon: not too fast: soft, soft! Unless the master were the man. How now! Even so quickly may one catch the plague? Methinks I feel this youth's perfections With an invisible and subtle stealth To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be. What ho, Malvolio!
Re-enter MALVOLIO

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Here, madam, at your service.

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: Run after that same peevish messenger, The county's man: he left this ring behind him, Would I or not: tell him I'll none of it. Desire him not to flatter with his lord, Nor hold him up with hopes; I am not for him: If that the youth will come this way to-morrow, I'll give him reasons for't: hie thee, Malvolio.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Madam, I will.
Exit

lines.speaker: olivia
lines.text: I do I know not what, and fear to find Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind. Fate, show thy force: ourselves we do not owe; What is decreed must be, and be this so.
Exit
